title: Will ACLED record any riot/protest events in Mozambique in October 2017?
preds: Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Report suggest rioting in Mozambique, although not sure it it meets ACLED criteria for inclusion.
Event has occurred based on two separate news sources discussed in forum.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
I don't feel this will happen.
Looks like a slam dunk: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/589521 and https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/588760
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
The ACLED October 7th update for Mozambique includes 2 riot/protest events for October, including 4 student deaths.

This event has not already occurred from what I observed from "allAfrica".  Yes, there was an armed attack but that is not the same as protests and riots.  After violence though, at least for this year there was not an apparent or strong correlation that I could see.  The first riot/protest occurred in May after a number of events from January to April that were also violent so I don't think you can draw a strong correlation between the two.  However, I do think the possibility is higher but by just a little bit because it does provide an event for people to organize around.
So yes because this already happened right?
fupdating as per post by dsarin
Responding to data provided by Dsarin at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/589521

Residents in Mozambique’s northeastern city of Nampula engaged in protests over the assassination of their mayor, Mahumudo Amurane.
http://www.africanews.com/2017/10/05/protests-after-assassination-of-mozambique-mayor-on-day-of-peace/
Anti-corruption mayor of Nampula City assassinated October 4.  https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2017/10/mozambique-killing-of-anti-corruption-mayor-must-be-investigated/

Adjusting in reaction to posts by @alwim and @Mos . According to ACLED's codebook, the event of Oct 2 is likely to be counted as a riot: among others according to ACLED riots are "spontaneous acts of violence by disorganised groups, which may target property, or businesses, or may involve clashes with other disorganised groups or security institutions (e.g. inter-communal actions that are spontaneous and disorganized are examples of this action)" (https://www.acleddata.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/ACLED_Codebook_2015.pdf).

Deutsche Welle is a source cited by ACLED.
http://www.dw.com/pt-002/populares-incendeiam-casa-de-comandante-da-pol%C3%ADcia-no-norte-de-mo%C3%A7ambique/a-40781795 The original story was picked up by Club of Mozambique media service (see alwim's post below).

It will be interesting to see if the ACLED will record the two following events in Mozambique as both Riots, or one Riot and one Protest or as a single event as a Riot or a Protest.  1.)	“Stray bullets”: Police admit four deaths in Mandimba, Niassa
The Mozambican police on Tuesday admitted that four people died on Monday, 10/02/2017, morning, when police opened fire on rioters in the town of Mandimba, in the northern province of Niassa. http://clubofmozambique.com/news/stray-bullets-police-admit-four-deaths-in-mandimba-niassa/ 2.)	A crowd in Mandimba, Niassa province, went on the rampage yesterday, 10/02/2017, after a money changer was killed on Sunday in an event they suspected involved the police. ... Mada said that “the demonstration lasted a long time, eventually vandalising the commander’s own house and burning two vehicles”, but did not say if there were any injuries.  In addition, and because “the situation was a bit chaotic,” the police dispatched “a force to Mandimba district to restore public order. We asked the border police stationed in that district to join the district command in order to calm down protesters and this happened,” he confirmed. http://clubofmozambique.com/news/mob-burns-down-police-commanders-residence-in-northern-mozambique/
Riots and protests are pretty common in Mozambique and no reason to expect any change in frequency at this point.
There has been one recorded in every month of 2017 so far!  It does seem to be slowing down, however.
Responding to the base rate analysis of @cpschneider at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/5855362. Thank you, Christian Schneider.

Taking months with relevant incidents as the unit of analysis, according to ACLED data, the rate of occurrence of riots in Mozambique in any given month is 39% in the past two decade. However, in the past decade (2007-2016) this rate was elevated with 71 out of 120 months or approximately 60%. Since the elections in 2009 months in which occurred were clearly more common compared to the previous years on record (70%). With the median number of months per year in which riots occurred being 8 between 2009 and 2016, in only one year since 2009, there were riots in less than half of all months (the current count is 4 according to ACLED data). Overall, 70% seems be a reasonably conservative base rate. If riots took place in October 2017, this would be the fourth consecutive month this years in which protests were recorded. According to the data, it is relatively unusual that riots take place in four or more months in a row. Overall, this was only the case five times in the past two decades. However, all of these instance took place in four of the five years between 2009 and 2016. The fact that October 2017 would be the fourth consecutive month in which riots were recorded should not influence the estimate.

(1) I could generally separate riots and protests into three groups: pay, politics, and violence.  Elections increased the rate of riots and protests in 2014 so when looking for the mean I wanted to exclude riots and protests directly tied to the election cycle because Mozambique held elections in 2014.  My question was how often do riots and protests occur that aren't about politics?  How often do they occur when they are about politics?  And what is the base rate of riots and protests per month? Riots/protests that aren't about politics occur at a base rate of about 1 per month.  In 2015 and 2016 there were (4) and (2) respectively that were political in nature.  There was (1) in 2017 so far. At this point Mozambique is below the mean baseline for riots and protests so there is a higher chance of one occurring.  But there were five straight months where nothing happens like January to April of this year.  Therefore, I think there is a 75% chance of a riot occurring in the next three months and a lower chance of a riot occurring in the next month.

I'm bumping this up a bit after a some additional research on events in Mozambique.  I think there are two key potential hotspots for protests: Tete province and Maputo City. Please see below:  Mozambique Paradox of Plenty Strikes With Bloody Consequence 
http://allafrica.com/stories/201709220604.html Long story short: Mining operations in Tete Province have caused locals to lose access to prior food, water, and grazing resources as well as introducing air and water pollution risks. Protesting and vandalism have occurred, and one peaceful protester was reportedly shot by police (though that seems to be in reference to a specific event in July - the article isn't clear). More flareups may be possible in the region.  Mozambique: Maputo Assembly Approves New Bus Fares
http://allafrica.com/stories/201709210890.html Bus fares in Maputo will be increasing in an attempt to incentivize more bus drivers to operate. This fare increase will take effect once newly consigned buses arrive in the city. The last increase, in 2012, prompted protests in the city.  There are at least two possible caveats to this, however: 1) The protests may occur in the next few days and fizzle before October and 2) Because the increase will only take effect once new buses arrive, the real sting of the fare increase will be delayed, and I have no idea when the new buses are supposed to arrive.
Thank you, @shivadiva, for contributing data in support of base rate calculations. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/572364

8 events this year in 9 months = .88 repeating per month in 2017
Of said events all but one were in last 3 months, so the rate is likely accelerating even beyond the .88 baseline.
If there will be a protest in Moz' it will might be because of the rising gas price

Taking base rate from dominich's calculation two days ago (which used more data than my very quick calculation). Unlike dominich, I'm not adjusting downward in response to 2017 being a light year for protests. The year as a whole has had a comparatively low rate of protests, but the rate is up in the past several months. I don't see a clear trend.

This is based on an assessment of previous years' monthly and daily likelihoods of riots or protests.  From the brief research that I've done, there doesn't seem to be an outstanding catalyst for protest this year like there have been in some previous years. I don't see a clear reason yet for October to deviate from long-term averages.
Been averaging 3-4 events per month in 2017.  Don't know much of anything about Mozambique but I'll just play the statistics here.

13 killed in price riots in september 2017
https://www.iol.co.za/business-report/technology/smses-suspended-in-mozambique-912013
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Recent Riot/Protest events in Mozambique:
Riots/Protests
10 May 2017 (Frelimo party youths broke up an MDM meeting, causing clashes between the 2 parties. )
12 July 2017 (Technical and administrative staff of Eduardo Mondlane University (UEM) begin a labour strike over non payment of bonuses. A violent protest over the issue occurred the following day. )
13 July 2017 (Staff of Eduardo Mondlane University violently protest over non-payment of bonuses. Riot force police used rubber bullets and tear gas grenades to disperse the demonstrators. No reported injuries. )
13 July 2017 (A stray bullet shot by police killed a worker during a protest in Moatize, causing the other workers to riot, vandalizing a generator and other company equipment. )
26 July 2017 (Workers at Maragra Sugar Mill, north of Maputo, began a strike to demand better wages.)
9 Aug 2017 (Workers at Maragra Sugar Mill rioted and destroyed property. The riot police were called in and clashed with the protesters. 2 civilians and 2 police officers were injured. )
4 Sept 2017 (Loggers in Manica protested the Manica Forest Industry company. So: 1 event in May; 4 events (2 of which were related) in July; 1 event in August (which was related to one of the July incidents); 1 incident in September.  = 7 events in 9 months =  0.77 events a month. Apart from the May event none of these are directly connected with unambigiously political-party questions; there are also no impending elections that might serve to aggregate social tensions. The brief description of the events suggests that most or all of these riots were not premediated, but occured in response to specific (and seemingly in one case accidental) events. Looking back at recent years: (the four year period from Sept 2013 to Aug 2017) There were 15 riot events between Sept and Dec 2013 = an average of 3.75 events per month. However, numerous incidents In November (and particularly late November) were directly related to (local?) elections – a type of event that will have no parallel during the period under consideration for this question. Therefore I think it reasonable to regard riot events that are directly associated with a domestic election as void for purposes of calculating averages for the purposes of this question, as they are liable to a time of untypically heightened tensions. When these events are excluded, there were still six riot events between Sept and Dec, giving an average of 1.5 per month, There were a large number of riot events in 2014, but they were mostly concentrated in a period of not much more than four weeks in September/October, coinciding with parliamentary elections.  If the whole of September and October 2014 are excluded from consideration (as being untypical), in the remainder of the year, there were 10 riot events during the course of the year.  (10 events in 10 months – 1 event a month.  (There were 31 events in Sept-Oct, of which 26 were directly related to the election, but the heightened tension maybe means excluding the period, rather than discrete events, may be more helpful.) Jan 2015 is also an atypical month, as three of the four riot events in that month were also directly related to political developments – the swearing-in of the new recently-elected parliament.  When those three events are excluded, there were a total of 18 riot events recorded during the year.  = 1.5 events per month.  2016: 15 events = 1.25 events a month In short, 2017 so far is exceptional among the last four calendar years in returning an average of under one event a month. However, another approach (and one that takes account that it is not uncommon for multiple riot events to occur in response to a common trigger incident, even outside election season):
In how many months since 2014 have no events been recorded?
Sept-Dec 2013: Dec
2014: April, June, August, November (4 out of 12:  events recorded in 8 out of 12 months: 0.67)
2015: February, May, July, August (4 out of 12:  events recorded in 8 out of 12 months: 0.67)
2016:  April ONLY (1 out of 12: events recorded in 11 out of 12 months: 0.92)
2017 to date: Jan, Feb, March, April, June (5 out of 8 months so far: events recorded in 3 of 8 m months: 0.375)
Aggregating this:  no riot events were recorded in 15 months out of the last 48 months.  Riot events were recorded in 33 of those 48 months  (0.69 of them) Taking 0.69 as the base rate for riot events, and adjusting down a little to take account both of the overall lower rate of events in 2017 compared with recent years, and the absence of any anticipated scheduled obvious probable triggers .

There have been protests in four of the past nine months. I don't see any pattern in the reasons for the protests; they appear to be about separate issues. So I'm taking 4/9 as an approximate base rate.
ACLED reports riots/protests in May/July/August/September 2017. Base rate for riot/protest events in Mozambique seems high.

Considering the reported type of causes, by ACLED, for recent riots and protests in Mozambique, it seems they are likely to happen throughout Mozambique in October. The reported causes were for disputes over wages for loggers, sugar cane mill workers, and staff bonuses at a university, and, the far more serious reports of police shootings that led to deaths and riots. For those caused by the police not to occur, it would require a major concerted police training program with emphasis on both crowd control and the appropriate use of force. Even if immediately implemented and with strong departmental and political backing plus strong civil and NGO watch groups, this would require months to accomplish. The labor wage issue could easily go on for months as well based on the gap that exists between management and workers. For these reasons, both protests and riots could easily break out in October. I am giving "easily break out" a 94% probability of happening. In addition, there are real tensions between the political opposition parties such as the Frelimo, MDM, and Renamo that could also lead to protests or riots.

Seven such incidents so far this year, above average and gaining some momentum ahead of October - the month that represents to seasonal peak for such activity. Economy appears relatively stable, if subdued. An impending peace deal between government and opposition forces should create a benign backdrop but could also bring grievances to the surface.
data for a short period of time in AlCED, situation hot (violence), but crop is good now (agriculture is 80% of Mozambique economy) and price of aluminie is high (55% of Mozamique export)

I count 1 in May, 4 in July, 1 in August, and 1 in September. Given those numbers it seems likely. That said, I'm having a hard time finding any good current news sources for goings-on in Mozambique. Does anyone have any recommendations?

There was one riot event in the month of August, two events in July, zero in June and one in May.  Mozambique is a country with a low number of events in the ACLED database, which is a good thing and an indicator of stability.  There are around 24 million people in the Southeastern African state.  I predict a riot event will take place in October 2017, because riot events are one of the most common type of incidents in Mozambique in the ACLED monthly database and the average of the last 4 months is 1 riot event per month.

Well there have been riots or protests with increasing frequency in the country this year, going from one in the first six months to six in the last three (counting September). And I realize that includes four in July. All that being said, I do think some sort of protest/riot is likely in the country. Looking more generally at the fundamentals, the government is running a huge budge shortfall following the revelation of two billion dollars secret government loans last year so there isn't money around to buy off protesters and disgruntled workers. I think the country is going to continue to experience low level instability for some time to come.
